BOEDMAS: integers and exponents

Without using your calculator, evaluate the following expression:

4−(−2)34−(−2)3

Note: If you use your calculator, you will not learn how to use BOEDMAS.

Answer: 4−(−2)34−(−2)3 =
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The ordering of BOEDMAS is the key here - this expression has an exponent, so that needs to be done first.

STEP: Remember what BOEDMAS tells us
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Whenever we evaluate an expression, we must follow the order of operations, BOEDMAS. Here is what BOEDMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later.
  2. "E" ⟶⟶ do any exponents; exponents always come before multiplication and division!
  3. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  4. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

So it is helpful to think of the order of operations as four steps: BO-E-DM-AS.

STEP: Start with the exponent
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

In this question, there are two operations: subtraction and an exponent. BOEDMAS tells us to start with the exponent. Since the base is negative, and the exponent is odd, evaluating the exponent will give us a negative number.

Then using this result, we need to do the subtraction. It is useful to organise our work into a nice funnel shape, as shown below, to keep track of all of our steps.

Therefore the final answer is 12.

What value will make the expression undefined?

What value must replace the symbol, to make each of the following expressions undefined?

  1. 7÷△7÷△
  2. 7⊡+27⊡+2
Answer:
  1. △=△=
  2. ⊡=⊡=
numeric
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Dividing by zero makes an expression undefined.

STEP: 1. 7÷△7÷△
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
Division by zero is undefined!

Therefore, △=0△=0.

STEP: 2. Find the value that will make the denominator equal to zero
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The denominator is ⊡+2⊡+2.

The expression will be undefined when ⊡+2=0⊡+2=0.

−2+2=0−2+2=0

Therefore, ⊡=−2⊡=−2.

ID is: 1742 Seed is: 1796

BODMAS: the order of operations including brackets

Complete this question without using a calculator. You should write down your working first, and then type in your final answer.

Find the value of this expression:

(3+4)×3(3+4)×3.

Answer:
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
You should think of BODMAS in three parts: BO-DM-AS. There are no brackets in this question, so start with any division or multiplication that you see. If you see them both, you must do them left to right, like when reading a sentence. After you do all of the division and multiplication, then you should do all of the addition and subtraction; these also should be done from left to right.
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Whenever you evaluate an expression, you must follow the order of operations, BODMAS. To summarize, here is what BODMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later
  2. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  3. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

Therefore, it is helpful to think of the order of operations in three pieces: BO-DM-AS.

We must use BO-DM-AS to evaluate this expression: (3+4)×3(3+4)×3. This expression includes addition and multiplication, but it also includes brackets! We always do the operations inside brackets before operations outside of the brackets! In this case that means we must start with addition, and the multiplication must wait.

Following BO-DM-AS, multiplication and division always come before addition and subtraction!

The calculation in brackets is highlighted in blue in the work below. After we finish the calculations in the brackets, we can leave the brackets off!

It is important for you to organise your working like the example above. Notice how the working comes down, in the shape of a funnel. Keeping your work organised like this will help you avoid mistakes!

The correct final answer is 2121.

    −3+[9−(−7)]−3+[9−(−7)]

    Note: If you use your calculator, you will not learn how to use BOEDMAS.

    Answer: −3+[9−(−7)]−3+[9−(−7)] =
    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    The first letter in BOEDMAS is "B", so you should start with the brackets before you evaluate the rest of the expression. In this question, the brackets that you need to look at are the square ones, since there are no operations inside the round brackets.

    STEP: Start with the brackets
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    In this question, we need to start at the beginning of BOEDMAS with "B" for brackets. Here, that means starting inside the square brackets, since there are no operations inside the round ones.

    Inside the brackets, we are doing subtraction. Specifically, we must evaluate 9−(−7)9−(−7). Since we are subtracting, and one of the numbers is negative and one is positive, the value inside the brackets will be 16.

    STEP: Do the operation outside the brackets
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    Now that we have done everything inside the brackets, we can do the calculation outside them.

    Since we are doing addition, the final solution will be 13.

    It is useful to organise our work in a nice funnel shape, to keep track of our steps as we do them.

    So the final answer is 13.

  2. Do the brackets in the expression affect the final value of the expression? In other words, if we take away the brackets, will the answer change or not?

    Answer:

    Did the brackets affect the final answer?

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    STEP: Evaluate the expression without any brackets
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Imagine there are no brackets in the expression, and instead it looks like:

    −3+9−(−7)−3+9−(−7)

    Will we still work out the answer in the same order that we did in Question 1?

    Since the operations in the expression are subtraction and addition, the order will not change.

    BOEDMAS tells us that addition and subtraction must happen from left to right. This is the same as what we did when the brackets were there. For the original expression, we did the subtraction, and then the addition. Without the brackets, we did the same thing.

    The calculations below show that the answer is the same as what we had in Question 1.

    The brackets will not change the final value of the expression. Therefore, the answer is No.

STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Whenever you evaluate an expression, you must follow the order of operations, BOEDMAS. To summarize, here is what BOEDMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later
  2. "E" ⟶⟶ do any exponents; exponents always come before multiplication and division!
  3. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  4. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

Therefore, it is helpful to think of the order of operations in four pieces: BO-E-DM-AS.

NOTE: There are brackets in this expression, but there are no operations inside of the brackets, only a single number. The 'BO' part of BOEDMAS tells us to start with the operations inside of brackets... in this expression there are no operations inside of brackets!

In this expression there are two operations: division and subtraction. Which one does BO-E-DM-AS say to do first? Because of 'DM-AS,' multiplication and division always come before addition and subtraction! Make sure you organise your work in a nice funnel shape, as shown below.

When we get to the second calculation, we need to simplify the signs in the expression: there is a double-negative, which should be changed into addition.

The correct final answer is 1111.

NOTE: Notice that this solution includes a step where subtraction changes into addition: this is the reason why we must do addition and subtraction from left to right - if they can mix like this, we must treat that as equals!

  4. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

Therefore, it is helpful to think of the order of operations in four pieces: BO-E-DM-AS.

NOTE: There are brackets in this expression, but there are no operations inside of the brackets, only a single number. The 'BO' part of BOEDMAS tells us to start with the operations inside of brackets... in this expression there are no operations inside of brackets!

In this expression there are two operations: multiplication and addition. Which one does BO-E-DM-AS say to do first? Because of 'DM-AS,' multiplication and division always come before addition and subtraction! Make sure you organise your work in a nice funnel shape, as shown below.

When we get to the second calculation, we need to simplify the signs in the expression: the calculation includes adding a negative number, which becomes subtraction.

The correct final answer is −20−20.

NOTE: Notice that this solution includes a step where addition changes into subtraction: this is the reason why we must do addition and subtraction from left to right - if they can mix like this, we must treat that as equals!

Commutative property

  1. For each of the following number sentences, select whether it is True or False.

    Answer:

    2. 3×1=1×33×1=1×3
    3. 31=1331=13
    4. 3÷1=1÷33÷1=1÷3
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Work out each sum and decide if it is true.

    STEP: Work out each sum and decide if it is true
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    1. True: 31=1×331=1×3

    31=331=3 and 1×3=31×3=3. But this is a special case - raising a number to a power is usually not the same as multiplying by that number!

    2. True: 3×1=1×33×1=1×3

    3×1=33×1=3 and 1×3=31×3=3. In fact, this is true for all numbers: we can multiply them in any order.

    3. False: 31≠1331≠13

    31=331=3 but 13=113=1. With exponents, the order matters!

    TIP: Exponents tell you how many times to multiply a number by itself. So 13=1×1×113=1×1×1.

    4. False: 3÷1≠1÷33÷1≠1÷3

    3÷1=33÷1=3 but 1÷3=131÷3=13. When we divide, the order matters!

BODMAS: the order of operations

Evaluate:

14+8−314+8−3

Answer: 14+8−3=14+8−3=
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

You should think of BODMAS in three parts: BO-DM-AS. There are no brackets in this question, so start with any division or multiplication that you see. If you see them both, you must do them left to right, like when reading a sentence. After you do all of the division and multiplication, then you should do all of the addition and subtraction; these also should be done from left to right.

STEP: Follow the order of operations
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Whenever you work out an expression, you must follow the order of operations, BODMAS. To summarize, here is what BODMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later
  2. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  3. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

Therefore, it is helpful to think of the order of operations in three pieces: BO-DM-AS.

We must use BO-DM-AS to evaluate this expression: 14+8−314+8−3.

This question includes addition and subtraction. Many people think that you must always add before you subtract because BO-DM-AS makes it look that way. However, addition and subtraction have equal 'strength:' one of them is not stronger than the other!

The correct way to do this calculation is to start with the operation on the left first, and then move to the right.

The first calculation we need to do is addition because it is on the left; then we will do the subtraction after that. (This step is highlighted with the blue underline and arrow.) Your working should be organised like this:

Notice how the working comes down, in the shape of a funnel. It is very important to organise your work like this: it will help you avoid mistakes!

The correct final answer is 1919.

Operations with zero

Calculate each of the following, if possible:

Answer:
  1. 762×0762×0
  2. 07620762
  3. 762÷0762÷0
  4. 762+0762+0
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]
  • When you add zero to any number, you don't change the number. The same is true if you subtract zero from a number.
  • When you multiply a number by zero, you get zero.
  • Zero divided by any number is zero.
  • Division by zero is undefined!
STEP: Use your knowledge of the properties of zero
[−4 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

1. 762×0=0762×0=0

When you multiply a number by zero, you get zero.

2. 0762=00762=0

Zero divided by any number (except zero) is zero.

Make sure that you can see the difference between dividing by zero and dividing zero by a number.

TIP: If you are wondering what to do with 0÷00÷0, you are going to be a great mathematician! Try out some definitions and see what happens.

3. 762÷0762÷0 is undefined.

Dividing by zero does funny things to numbers. Mathematicians say that it is undefined because we can't find one answer that makes sense.

Let's says that maybe 762÷0762÷0 gives us 00. But, division is the opposite of multiplication. So, if this is true then 0×00×0 must give us 762762! We definitely don't want that. So, dividing by zero can't give us zero.

The same kind of thing happens no matter how we try to define division by zero.

Division by zero is undefined.

4. 762+0=762762+0=762

When you add zero to any number, you don't change the number.
Submit your answer as: andandand
